title: 111_hr2772
content: The "SBIR and STTR Enhancement Act" increases the number of research topic solicitations annually and shortens the period for final decisions on applications to 90 days, with a possible extension to 180 days on a case by case basis. SEC. 3 amends the Small Business Act to require annual reporting on small businesses receiving multiple first phase SBIR awards. SEC. 4 addresses federal agency engagement with SBIR awardees who have received multiple phase one awards but no phase two awards. Section 9 of the Small Business Act is amended to require federal agencies conducting SBIR programs to engage with SBIR awardees who have received multiple first phase awards but no second phase awards, and to develop performance measures for awardee progression in the program. Funding for administrative, oversight, and contract processing costs is also addressed. Section 9 of the Small Business Act is amended to allow the Administrator to transfer funds to federal agencies for administrative, oversight, and contract processing costs related to SBIR programs. Rules for transfers must be established within 180 days of enactment, with a limit of 3 transfers per fiscal year for each agency. The Small Business Act allows the Administrator to transfer funds to federal agencies for SBIR program costs, with a limit of 3 transfers per fiscal year. An amount greater than 3 percent of the SBIR budget of an agency can be allocated under this subsection. $27,500,000 is authorized for each of fiscal years 2010 and 2011. The Comptroller General will audit how Federal agencies calculate extramural research budgets for the Small Business Innovation Research Program and Small Business Technology Transfer Program budgets. A report on the audit results will be submitted to relevant committees within 1 year of the Act's enactment. Section 9(k) of the Small Business Act is amended to include new requirements for information on the ownership structure of award recipients. Federal agencies are required to update information for their database before making Phase I or Phase II payments to small business concerns. The Small Business Act now requires small business concerns to provide all necessary information for awards received under this section, including apportioning sales or investment information for multiple awards. Additionally, annual updates are required for award recipients under this section. The Small Business Act mandates that businesses receiving awards must update information in databases at the end of the award period. Recipients may be asked to voluntarily update information annually for 5 years, with small businesses required to do so for subsequent awards. Each Federal agency with an SBIR or STTR program must maintain a database for program evaluation purposes. The database should contain necessary information and be accessible to other agencies. It should contribute to oversight and evaluation of the programs. Federal agencies with SBIR or STTR programs must maintain databases for program evaluation, contributing to oversight and evaluation of the programs. Each Federal agency with an SBIR or STTR program must create and maintain a technology utilization database for award recipients to attract customers, investors, and business partners. Participation in the database is voluntary, except for award recipients who are required to participate. The technology utilization database created by Federal agencies for SBIR and STTR program recipients is mandatory for those who received supplemental payments above their initial Phase II award. The database must contribute to the agency's oversight and evaluation of the programs. SEC. 9. INTERAGENCY POLICY COMMITTEE. The Interagency SBIR/STTR Policy Committee, chaired by the Directors of the Office of Science and Technology Policy and the National Institute of Standards and Technology, will review issues related to improving program effectiveness and efficiency, including databases and award sizes. The Interagency SBIR/STTR Policy Committee will review award sizes and criteria for flexibility, commercialization assistance best practices, and funding gaps for business concerns post-Phase II. Reports will be transmitted to relevant committees within a year of the Act's enactment. The Interagency SBIR/STTR Policy Committee will provide reports on its review and recommendations under subsection (c)(2) within 18 months and under subsection (c)(3) within 2 years of the Act's enactment. SEC. 10. National Research Council SBIR Study amends the Small Business Reauthorization Act of 2000. SEC. 11. Express Authority to "Fast-Track" Phase Two Awards for Promising Phase One Research. Section 9 of the Small Business Act is amended to allow Federal agencies with SBIR programs to develop 'fast-track' programs to expedite Phase Two awards after Phase One research. The Administrator will encourage the development of such programs. The Small Business Act is amended to increase SBIR and STTR award levels. SBIR program awards will be increased to $250,000 in the first phase and $2,000,000 in the second phase, with mandatory annual adjustments. STTR program awards will also be increased to the same amounts. The Small Business Act is amended to limit SBIR and STTR awards to $250,000 in the first phase and $2,000,000 in the second phase, with annual adjustments. No federal agency can issue awards exceeding these amounts, except with agency head approval. The agency can apply for an exception to issue awards exceeding the specified amounts by notifying the Administrator and reporting to relevant committees annually. SEC. 13 allows agencies to award additional second phase SBIR awards for projects. Agencies can provide testing and evaluation assistance for the insertion of SBIR technologies into technical or weapons systems. SEC. 14 mandates the first phase for SBIR-funded projects. SEC. 14 mandates that a Federal agency must award a small business concern the second phase of an SBIR program only if they have received an award for the first phase or completed necessary determinations.
